text.description: According to Euromonitor, Delfi commands c.40% of Indonesia’s chocolate confectionery market based on retail value in 2020. Its flagship brand, SilverQueen, is also the leading brand in the nation. Indonesia is a key driver to Delfi’s profitability, generating c.70% of its sales and more than c.90% of its EBITDA over the past five years (FY15-20). Despite Covid-19, Delfi’s sales recovered from the trough of US$70.5m in 2Q20 to a normalised level of US$119.4m in 1Q21. Given Delfi’s established presence in Indonesia, we expect sales momentum to grow beyond pre-Covid-19 levels by FY22F, supporting EPS growth of 15%/16%/4% for FY21F/FY22F/FY23F.
text.title: Delfi Ltd - Sweet Delight

text.description: STE Commercial Aerospace’s production of engine nacelle (US subsidiary, MRAS) and floor paneling (German subsidiary, EFW) is set to recover as Airbus gradually ramps up monthly production of A320 aircraft. In May, Airbus guided its global suppliers that the group targets to increase A320 aircraft production to 45/month by 4Q21F (from current 40/month) and 64/month by 2Q23F. This is higher than 55/month in Feb 2020 during early stages of Covid-19. Airbus is also asking suppliers to prepare for a scenario of 70/month by 1Q24F and potentially 75/month by 2025F (pre-Covid-19 target was 60/month in 2019).
text.title: ST Engineering - Big and agile

text.description: The economic recovery in the US remains sturdy as highlighted by the latest Consumer Confidence data. The Conference Board Consumer Confidence Index improved further in June to 127.3, a new 16-month high.

text.description: Kimly is one of the largest coffee shop operators in Singapore with 72 coffee shops as at end-Sep 20. We forecast a 2-year core EPS CAGR of 47% in FY20-22F on the back of tailwinds from continued work-from-home (WFH) initiatives, increased popularity of food delivery services and earnings contribution from new acquisition, Tenderfresh.
text.title: Kimly Group - Delightful flavours

text.description: Following the FOMC meeting on Wednesday, the Fed signaled as much as two rate hikes in 2023 according to the Dot-Plot projections.
text.title: US Market Insights

text.description: SGX’s multi-year journey of building a multi-asset platform is coming together, with management piecing together its strategic moves during its analyst day presentation. SGX aims to leverage on cyclical trends (such as the low interest rate environment as investors yield hunt) and inflationary concerns (increased market volatility) to support its multi-asset strategy, while leaning into secular trends, such as a rising focus on ESG investing (offering risk management products), a growing demand for digitalisation in OTC FX and fixed income (building an integrated FX marketplace across futures/OTC with BidFX and a digital end-to-end fixed income issuance and trading platform via MarketNode and Trumid XT), and growth in passive investing (via Scientific Beta, SB).
text.title: Digital edge for Singapore Exchange

text.description: With another disappointing US Jobs report in May, marking the second consecutive month of weaker than expected nonfarm payroll, the weakness continues to justify for a patient Fed with a wait and see approach. May added 559,000 jobs, below the market consensus of 645,000.

text.description: After a disappointing print in April with Manufacturing PMI missing expectations, May proved that the general economic recovery remains on track. The latest Manufacturing PMI came in at 61.2, an increase of 0.5 percentage points from April, beating expectations. Notably, this marks the 12 consecutive month of growth following the recovery from the Covid-19 shut down last year.

text.description: Not much has changed in the latest FOMC meeting in April as the Fed kept the benchmark interest rates at 0.25% and maintain the $120 billion per month bond buying program. text.description: Looking at the recent release of the economic data continues to paint a healthy recovery. Notably, the ISM Service PMI rose to a new 15 year high at 63.7 in March, marking the 10 consecutive month of expansion, further validating the strong resilient economic growth. Adding to the optimism, the labor market data reported last week was surprisingly strong as well. The unemployment rate continued to fall to 6% in March from the Covid-19 high of 14.7%. March also saw 916,000 jobs added, greatly exceeding the median estimate of 660,000. All in, with the recently announced $2.25 trillion infrastructure bill and further reopening of the economy, expect the recovery to accelerate. Any pullbacks in the market present a better buying opportunity.
text.title: US Market insights

text.description: The vaccine drive in the US appears to be winning as the original goal of 100 million shots administered was achieved on day 58 of the Biden administration and President Biden has doubled the goal to 200 million shots by end of April.
text.title: Us Market Insights

text.description: Over the week, Fed Chairman, Powell continued to reassure the market that there will not be any interest rate hike any time soon until the inflation and employment goals are met. Despite the 10 year yield rising to a high of 1.75%, pricing in a higher inflation expectation, Powell reiterated that the upward pressure on inflation will be temporary.
text.title: US Market Insights

text.description: Following the FOMC meeting on Wednesday, the market had a wild ride as the 10-Year Treasury Yield initially stabilized before breaking higher again on Thursday to a new 14-month high at 1.75%. As a result, the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 index fell -2.8% on Thursday.
text.title: US Market Insights

text.description: Headquartered in Singapore, Japfa specialises in producing protein staples (poultry, beef, swine and aquaculture), quality dairy and packaged food that nourish millions of people.  With a large employee count of over 40,000 people across an integrated network of modern farming, processing and distribution facilities in Indonesia, Vietnam, Myanmar, India and China, Japfa has grown to become leaders in multiple protein foods by embracing an integrated industrialised approach to farming and food production across the entire value chain over the past five decades . Their large-scale standardised operations allow them to consistently produce high quality proteins and to replicate their business model across different markets and protein types.  In this session, meet Japfa's Chief Financial Officer as he gives a brief overview of Japfa Group, its financial and operational highlights for FY2020 and the company's latest developments.
text.title: Company Snapshot: Japfa Ltd

text.description: The index’s performance this year largely tracked the progress of the US–China trade talks, given the latter’s outsized impact on global trade. GDP growth for the year was relatively muted, though Singapore managed to avoid a technical recession.

text.description: The Singapore equity market is mostly a bottom-up market. Companies have growing earnings exposure from outside of Singapore, making the health of Singapore’s economy increasingly irrelevant, and the well-being of ASEAN and Asia relevant.

text.title: Suntec REIT: Deepens footprint in Australia

text.description: Its net cash position and track record give GENS a strong chance of winning urban/regional IR in Japan that may accrete 18-23/7 Scts to FY20F fair value.  On the home front, we estimate RWS 2.0 could spur GENS’s non-gaming revenue up to S$1.2bn in FY26F (vs. FY18: S$834m).  GENS is in crucial long-term transformation mode and we like its current compelling valuation of 6.5x FY20F EV/EBITDA. Maintain Add.
text.title: Genting Singapore: Playing a crucial hand

text.description: Our recent Singapore strategy marketing tour saw investors finding their feet at more attractive entry levels after the 12-16% sell-down in May 2019.  Concerns centered around a Fed rate cut (could de-rate sector), the threat of virtual banks (low in near term), and NIM expansion (optimistic for 2Q19).  Maintain Neutral. Cross border business flows and loan growth still muted. Strong asset quality and robust capital are main support pillars for the sector.
text.title: Banks: Enough pie to be shared, virtual bank or not

text.description: SIA contract, cargo outlook, associates’ returns and M&A pipeline were the main subjects of questions by investors in HK during our NDR with SATS.  We like SATS as a proxy for secular growth in air travel but its investments and gestation may require investor patience in the short term.  We trim our FY20-22F EPS by 2.0-5.5% to reflect higher costs and gestation from investments. Maintain Add with lower TP of S$5.40 (previously S$5.46).
text.title: SATS Ltd - NDR takeaways: Seeding for growth

text.description: CIT launched a second takeover offer for the 34.8% stake in M&C it does not own at 6.85/share.  We expect the deal to be RNAV-accretive to CIT and allow greater flexibility to maneuver in a competitive landscape.  Maintain Add. Our TP of $10.66 is based on 35% discount to RNAV.
text.title: City Developments: Second takeover offer for M&C

text.description: FY3/19 core PATMI of S$19.1m met our and consensus expectations; down 14.5% yoy due to higher financing costs, despite 38.6% yoy topline growth.  We estimate cinema restructuring to add S$1m-1.5m EBITDA in FY20F, with tailwinds from strong blockbuster pipeline and more active sales initiatives.  We like mm2 for its earnings recovery, cheap valuation of 9.9x FY21F P/E and as a proxy for rising Asian content.
text.title: mm2 Asia: Look for organic growth in FY20F

text.description: SEIL has been operating at 73% in the past two months; SGPL to ride on lower coal costs; Wind power +27% yoy to 1,177MW, hopefully 1,727MW by 3Q19; Trading at -1 s.d. of 10-year mean, maintain Add and TP of S$3.41
text.title: Sembcorp Industries: Patience will pay off in India
